senses.de: Useless or worthless material, substances, or by-products
senses.ex: Industries should effectively manage their waste

Tips.title: Environmental concern
Tips.description: Waste is often linked with pollution and the need for recycling.
Tips.example: Reducing waste helps protect the environment.

Tips.title: Negative connotation
Tips.description: Waste implies something is not being used properly or is left over without a purpose.
Tips.example: Food waste is a serious issue.

senses.de: Use or expend carelessly, extravagantly, or to no purpose
senses.ex: We can't afford to waste electricity

Tips.title: Carelessness implied
Tips.description: Using 'waste' as a verb can suggest carelessness or lack of consideration.
Tips.example: Don't waste water while brushing your teeth.

Tips.title: Opportunity loss
Tips.description: To waste also means to lose an opportunity by not using it wisely or effectively.
Tips.example: Wasting your talents on trivial tasks is unwise.

senses.de: An act or instance of using or expending something carelessly, extravagantly, or to no purpose
senses.ex: It's a waste of time to argue

Tips.title: Expressing regret
Tips.description: This noun form often expresses regret over lost time, money, or effort.
Tips.example: Missing the event was a complete waste.

senses.ex: A vast track of waste land

Tips.title: Unused space
Tips.description: Describes land that is not being used, often desolate and barren.
Tips.example: The building was surrounded by waste land.

Tips.title: Not necessarily dirty
Tips.description: Waste land does not mean polluted, just unused or barren.
Tips.example: They planned to turn the waste into a garden.

senses.de: Cause to feel shocked or stunned
senses.ex: The tough loss wasted the whole team

Tips.title: Emotional impact
Tips.description: This usage can imply that something deeply affects a person's morale.
Tips.example: The constant criticism really wasted his enthusiasm.

Debris.wordDefinition:
Debris refers to pieces of materials or objects that are scattered around after a disaster or an accident, such as broken bricks, fallen trees, and damaged furniture.

Debris is the aftermath of a destructive event, while waste is the byproduct of regular human activities.

Excess.wordDefinition:
Excess means having too much of something beyond what is needed or required. For example, if you eat too much food, it is considered excess.

Excess is applicable when there is more than necessary, but the item or resource is still valuable and useful.

Excess means having more than necessary, but the item or resource is still valuable and useful. Waste means using something unnecessarily or carelessly, resulting in it being unusable or thrown away.

Garbage.wordDefinition:
Garbage refers to organic and biodegradable waste, such as food scraps and yard trimmings, while waste refers to all other forms of waste, including non-biodegradable substances like plastics and metals.

Garbage is typically collected separately and composted while waste is often recycled or disposed of in a landfill. Both words can be used interchangeably to refer to the disposal of unwanted materials, but garbage is usually associated with organic waste while waste is a more general term.

Litter.wordDefinition: Litter refers to small pieces of garbage or waste that are scattered around, like candy wrappers or cigarette butts.

Refuse.wordDefinition:
Refuse refers to things that are discarded or rejected because they are unwanted, unsatisfactory, or have no use.

It can also refer to the act of refusing to do something or accept something.

In other words, refuse is something that is already considered waste and is thrown away, while waste is something that could potentially be used or recycled but is not being used effectively.

Refuse is applicable when something is completely useless or unwanted, while waste is applicable when something is being used inefficiently or inappropriately.

Remainder.wordDefinition:
Remainder refers to what is left over after subtracting a certain amount or portion from a whole. For example, if you have 10 apples and you give away 3, the remainder is 7 apples.

In essence, the difference between the two words is that remainder refers to what is left over after something has been taken away, while waste refers to something that is no longer useful or necessary.

The term remainder is more applicable when dealing with numbers or quantities, while waste applies more broadly to a range of things that may be wasted or left unused.

Rubbish.wordDefinition:
Rubbish refers to things that are no longer needed or wanted, but still have some use.

Rubbish is used when referring to things that still have some value, while waste is used when referring to things that have no value and must be thrown away.

Scrap.wordDefinition:
Scrap refers to material that has value or can be repurposed, such as metal or paper. Waste refers to material that has no use and is typically thrown away, such as garbage or sewage.

Scrap is applicable when there is potential to reuse or recycle the material, while waste is applicable when something is no longer useful and needs to be disposed of.

quotes.Text: You can't live your life blaming your failures on your parents and what they did or didn't do for you. You're dealt the cards that you're dealt. I realised it was a waste of time to be angry at my parents and feel sorry for myself.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Drew Barrymore

quotes.Text: Try and leave this world a little better than you found it, and when your turn comes to die, you can die happy in feeling that at any rate, you have not wasted your time but have done your best.
quotes.Title: English Soldier
quotes.Name: Robert Baden-Powell

quotes.Text: Drugs are a waste of time. They destroy your memory and your self-respect and everything that goes along with with your self-esteem. They're no good at all.
quotes.Title: American Singer
quotes.Name: Kurt Cobain

quotes.Text: I balanced all, brought all to mind, the years to come seemed waste of breath, a waste of breath the years behind, in balance with this life, this death.
quotes.Title: Irish Poet
quotes.Name: William Butler Yeats

quotes.Text: Life being very short, and the quiet hours of it few, we ought to waste none of them in reading valueless books.
quotes.Title: English Writer
quotes.Name: John Ruskin

quotes.Text: A man who dares to waste one hour of time has not discovered the value of life.
quotes.Title: English Scientist
quotes.Name: Charles Darwin

quotes.Text: If you love life, don't waste time, for time is what life is made up of.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Bruce Lee

quotes.Text: There is no waste of time in life like that of making explanations.
quotes.Title: British Statesman
quotes.Name: Benjamin Disraeli

quotes.Text: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted.
quotes.Title: Greek Author
quotes.Name: Aesop

quotes.Text: Life is wasted on the living.
quotes.Title: English Writer
quotes.Name: Douglas Adams
